natural problem: Given the nine-sided regular polygon $A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_6A_7A_8A_9$, how many distinct equilateral triangles in the plane of the polygon have at least two vertices in the set $\{A_1, A_2, \ldots A_9\}$?
natural solution: Each of the $\binom{9}{2} = 36$ pairs of vertices determines two equilateral triangles, for a total of 72 triangles.
However, the three triangles $A_1A_4A_7$, $A_2A_5A_8$, and $A_3A_6A_9$ are each counted 3 times, resulting in an overcount of 6.
Thus, there are $\boxed{66}$ distinct equilateral triangles.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes vertices :: "int set" and equilateral_triangles :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "card vertices = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall>v1 v2 v3. (v1, v2, v3) \<in> equilateral_triangles \<longrightarrow> card {v1, v2, v3} = 2"
and h2 : "\<forall>v1 v2 v3. (v1, v2, v3) \<in> equilateral_triangles \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>A1 A2 A3 A4 A5 A6 A7 A8 A9. {v1, v2, v3} \<subseteq> {A1, A2, A3, A4, A5, A6, A7, A8, A9} \<and> distinct [A1, A2, A3, A4, A5, A6, A7, A8, A9])"
shows  "card equilateral_triangles = 66"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given the nine-sided regular polygon $A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_6A_7A_8A_9$, how many distinct equilateral triangles in the plane of the polygon have at least two vertices in the set $\{A_1, A_2, \ldots A_9\}$? The final Answer is 66
 ### Proof
 Each of the $\binom{9}{2} = 36$ pairs of vertices determines two equilateral triangles, for a total of 72 triangles.
 However, the three triangles $A_1A_4A_7$, $A_2A_5A_8$, and $A_3A_6A_9$ are each counted 3 times, resulting in an overcount of 6.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{66}$ distinct equilateral triangles.
 *)

theorem
fixes vertices :: "int set" and equilateral_triangles :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "card vertices = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall>v1 v2 v3. (v1, v2, v3) \<in> equilateral_triangles \<longrightarrow> card {v1, v2, v3} = 2"
and h2 : "\<forall>v1 v2 v3. (v1, v2, v3) \<in> equilateral_triangles \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>A1 A2 A3 A4 A5 A6 A7 A8 A9. {v1, v2, v3} \<subseteq> {A1, A2, A3, A4, A5, A6, A7, A8, A9} \<and> distinct [A1, A2, A3, A4, A5, A6, A7, A8, A9])"
shows  "card equilateral_triangles = 66"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 9 vertices and a set of equilateral triangles. Each equilateral triangle consists of 2 distinct vertices from the set of 9 vertices. How many different equilateral triangles can be formed using these vertices? The final answer is 66.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat set" and T :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..9}"
and h1 : "card A = 9"
and h2 : "distinct_equilateral_triangles A T"
shows  "card T = 66"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given the nine-sided regular polygon $A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_6A_7A_8A_9$, how many distinct equilateral triangles in the plane of the polygon have at least two vertices in the set $\{A_1, A_2, \ldots A_9\}$? The final Answer is 66
 ### Proof
 Each of the $\binom{9}{2} = 36$ pairs of vertices determines two equilateral triangles, for a total of 72 triangles.
 However, the three triangles $A_1A_4A_7$, $A_2A_5A_8$, and $A_3A_6A_9$ are each counted 3 times, resulting in an overcount of 6.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{66}$ distinct equilateral triangles.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat set" and T :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..9}"
and h1 : "card A = 9"
and h2 : "distinct_equilateral_triangles A T"
shows  "card T = 66"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many distinct equilateral triangles can be formed using the elements from the set A, where A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9}, and A has 9 elements? The final answer is 66.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> 'a" and num_triangles :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..9} \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>p q r. distinct [p, q, r] \<and> p \<in> {1..9} \<and> q \<in> {1..9} \<and> r \<in> {1..9} \<and> A p \<noteq> A q \<and> A p \<noteq> A r \<and> A q \<noteq> A r \<and> A i \<in> {A p, A q, A r})"
and h1 : "num_triangles = card {T. \<exists>p q r. T = {A p, A q, A r} \<and> distinct [p, q, r] \<and> p \<in> {1..9} \<and> q \<in> {1..9} \<and> r \<in> {1..9} \<and> A p \<noteq> A q \<and> A p \<noteq> A r \<and> A q \<noteq> A r \<and> (\<exists>i. i \<in> {1..9} \<and> A i \<in> T)}"
shows  "num_triangles = 66"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given the nine-sided regular polygon $A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_6A_7A_8A_9$, how many distinct equilateral triangles in the plane of the polygon have at least two vertices in the set $\{A_1, A_2, \ldots A_9\}$? The final Answer is 66
 ### Proof
 Each of the $\binom{9}{2} = 36$ pairs of vertices determines two equilateral triangles, for a total of 72 triangles.
 However, the three triangles $A_1A_4A_7$, $A_2A_5A_8$, and $A_3A_6A_9$ are each counted 3 times, resulting in an overcount of 6.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{66}$ distinct equilateral triangles.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> 'a" and num_triangles :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..9} \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>p q r. distinct [p, q, r] \<and> p \<in> {1..9} \<and> q \<in> {1..9} \<and> r \<in> {1..9} \<and> A p \<noteq> A q \<and> A p \<noteq> A r \<and> A q \<noteq> A r \<and> A i \<in> {A p, A q, A r})"
and h1 : "num_triangles = card {T. \<exists>p q r. T = {A p, A q, A r} \<and> distinct [p, q, r] \<and> p \<in> {1..9} \<and> q \<in> {1..9} \<and> r \<in> {1..9} \<and> A p \<noteq> A q \<and> A p \<noteq> A r \<and> A q \<noteq> A r \<and> (\<exists>i. i \<in> {1..9} \<and> A i \<in> T)}"
shows  "num_triangles = 66"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 9 distinct objects, labeled A(1) through A(9). In how many ways can they be partitioned into 66 groups of 3 objects each, such that each group contains exactly one of the objects A(i), where i is an integer from 1 to 9, and no two groups have the same combination of objects?

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat and equilateral_triangles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. equilateral_triangles k = (k * (k - 1) * (k - 2)) div 6"
and h2 : "equilateral_triangles n \<ge> 2"
shows  "equilateral_triangles n = 66"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given the nine-sided regular polygon $A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_6A_7A_8A_9$, how many distinct equilateral triangles in the plane of the polygon have at least two vertices in the set $\{A_1, A_2, \ldots A_9\}$? The final Answer is 66
 ### Proof
 Each of the $\binom{9}{2} = 36$ pairs of vertices determines two equilateral triangles, for a total of 72 triangles.
 However, the three triangles $A_1A_4A_7$, $A_2A_5A_8$, and $A_3A_6A_9$ are each counted 3 times, resulting in an overcount of 6.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{66}$ distinct equilateral triangles.
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat and equilateral_triangles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. equilateral_triangles k = (k * (k - 1) * (k - 2)) div 6"
and h2 : "equilateral_triangles n \<ge> 2"
shows  "equilateral_triangles n = 66"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: How many equilateral triangles can be formed using the vertices of a regular nonagon (9-sided polygon) as triangle vertices? The final answer is 66.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes vertices :: "nat set" and eq_triangles :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card vertices = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall>triangle \<in> eq_triangles. card triangle = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall>triangle \<in> eq_triangles. card (triangle \<inter> vertices) \<ge> 2"
shows  "card eq_triangles = 66"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given the nine-sided regular polygon $A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_6A_7A_8A_9$, how many distinct equilateral triangles in the plane of the polygon have at least two vertices in the set $\{A_1, A_2, \ldots A_9\}$? The final Answer is 66
 ### Proof
 Each of the $\binom{9}{2} = 36$ pairs of vertices determines two equilateral triangles, for a total of 72 triangles.
 However, the three triangles $A_1A_4A_7$, $A_2A_5A_8$, and $A_3A_6A_9$ are each counted 3 times, resulting in an overcount of 6.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{66}$ distinct equilateral triangles.
 *)

theorem
fixes vertices :: "nat set" and eq_triangles :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card vertices = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall>triangle \<in> eq_triangles. card triangle = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall>triangle \<in> eq_triangles. card (triangle \<inter> vertices) \<ge> 2"
shows  "card eq_triangles = 66"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: There are 9 distinct points (vertices). Let's consider a set of equilateral triangles, each of which has 3 vertices. If every equilateral triangle has at least 2 of its vertices in the set of 9 distinct points, find the total number of equilateral triangles in the set. The final answer is 66.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and distinct_equilateral_triangles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "distinct_equilateral_triangles n = (n * (n - 1) * (n - 2)) div 6"
shows  "distinct_equilateral_triangles n = 66"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given the nine-sided regular polygon $A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_6A_7A_8A_9$, how many distinct equilateral triangles in the plane of the polygon have at least two vertices in the set $\{A_1, A_2, \ldots A_9\}$? The final Answer is 66
 ### Proof
 Each of the $\binom{9}{2} = 36$ pairs of vertices determines two equilateral triangles, for a total of 72 triangles.
 However, the three triangles $A_1A_4A_7$, $A_2A_5A_8$, and $A_3A_6A_9$ are each counted 3 times, resulting in an overcount of 6.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{66}$ distinct equilateral triangles.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and distinct_equilateral_triangles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "distinct_equilateral_triangles n = (n * (n - 1) * (n - 2)) div 6"
shows  "distinct_equilateral_triangles n = 66"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: How many distinct equilateral triangles can be formed by choosing three vertices from a set of 9 non-collinear points? The final answer is 66.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat set" and equilateral_triangles :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "card A = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall>T. is_equilateral T \<and> (\<exists>a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> distinct_vertices a b T) \<longrightarrow> T \<in> equilateral_triangles"
and h2 : "card equilateral_triangles = 66"
shows  "number_of_equilateral_triangles_with_two_vertices_in_A A = 66"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given the nine-sided regular polygon $A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_6A_7A_8A_9$, how many distinct equilateral triangles in the plane of the polygon have at least two vertices in the set $\{A_1, A_2, \ldots A_9\}$? The final Answer is 66
 ### Proof
 Each of the $\binom{9}{2} = 36$ pairs of vertices determines two equilateral triangles, for a total of 72 triangles.
 However, the three triangles $A_1A_4A_7$, $A_2A_5A_8$, and $A_3A_6A_9$ are each counted 3 times, resulting in an overcount of 6.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{66}$ distinct equilateral triangles.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat set" and equilateral_triangles :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "card A = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall>T. is_equilateral T \<and> (\<exists>a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> distinct_vertices a b T) \<longrightarrow> T \<in> equilateral_triangles"
and h2 : "card equilateral_triangles = 66"
shows  "number_of_equilateral_triangles_with_two_vertices_in_A A = 66"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a set $A$ of 9 distinct points, there are 66 equilateral triangles such that each triangle has two of its vertices in the set $A$. How many equilateral triangles can be formed using these 9 points in set $A$? The final answer is 66.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n_points_on_polygon :: nat and n_equilateral_triangles :: nat
assumes h0 : "n_points_on_polygon = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> triangle. (\<exists> A B C. triangle = {A, B, C} \<and> A \<noteq> B \<and> A \<noteq> C \<and> B \<noteq> C
  \<and> (\<exists> distinct_indices. distinct distinct_indices \<and> set distinct_indices \<subseteq> {1..n_points_on_polygon}
  \<and> (card (set distinct_indices \<inter> {A, B, C}) \<ge> 2))) \<longrightarrow> n_equilateral_triangles = 66"
shows  "n_equilateral_triangles = 66"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given the nine-sided regular polygon $A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_6A_7A_8A_9$, how many distinct equilateral triangles in the plane of the polygon have at least two vertices in the set $\{A_1, A_2, \ldots A_9\}$? The final Answer is 66
 ### Proof
 Each of the $\binom{9}{2} = 36$ pairs of vertices determines two equilateral triangles, for a total of 72 triangles.
 However, the three triangles $A_1A_4A_7$, $A_2A_5A_8$, and $A_3A_6A_9$ are each counted 3 times, resulting in an overcount of 6.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{66}$ distinct equilateral triangles.
 *)

theorem
fixes n_points_on_polygon :: nat and n_equilateral_triangles :: nat
assumes h0 : "n_points_on_polygon = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> triangle. (\<exists> A B C. triangle = {A, B, C} \<and> A \<noteq> B \<and> A \<noteq> C \<and> B \<noteq> C
  \<and> (\<exists> distinct_indices. distinct distinct_indices \<and> set distinct_indices \<subseteq> {1..n_points_on_polygon}
  \<and> (card (set distinct_indices \<inter> {A, B, C}) \<ge> 2))) \<longrightarrow> n_equilateral_triangles = 66"
shows  "n_equilateral_triangles = 66"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A polygon has 9 points. How many equilateral triangles can be formed using at least 2 points from the polygon? The final answer is 66.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat set" and n :: nat and equilateral_triangles :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card A = 9"
and h1 : "regular_polygon A"
and h2 : "\<forall>t \<in> equilateral_triangles. \<exists>a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> card (t \<inter> A) \<ge> 2"
and h3 : "n = card equilateral_triangles"
shows  "n = 66"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given the nine-sided regular polygon $A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_6A_7A_8A_9$, how many distinct equilateral triangles in the plane of the polygon have at least two vertices in the set $\{A_1, A_2, \ldots A_9\}$? The final Answer is 66
 ### Proof
 Each of the $\binom{9}{2} = 36$ pairs of vertices determines two equilateral triangles, for a total of 72 triangles.

 Thus, there are $\boxed{66}$ distinct equilateral triangles.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat set" and n :: nat and equilateral_triangles :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card A = 9"
and h1 : "regular_polygon A"
and h2 : "\<forall>t \<in> equilateral_triangles. \<exists>a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> card (t \<inter> A) \<ge> 2"
and h3 : "n = card equilateral_triangles"
shows  "n = 66"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a regular 9-sided polygon, how many equilateral triangles can be formed such that each triangle has at least 2 vertices in common with the polygon? The final answer is 66.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n_equilateral_triangles :: nat
assumes h0 : "n_equilateral_triangles = card {T. T \<subseteq> {A1, A2, A3, A4, A5, A6, A7, A8, A9} \<and> (\<exists> P Q R. P \<in> T \<and> Q \<in> T \<and> R \<in> T \<and> dist P Q = dist Q R \<and> dist P R = dist Q R)}"
shows  "n_equilateral_triangles = 66"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given the nine-sided regular polygon $A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_6A_7A_8A_9$, how many distinct equilateral triangles in the plane of the polygon have at least two vertices in the set $\{A_1, A_2, \ldots A_9\}$? The final Answer is 66
 ### Proof
 Each of the $\binom{9}{2} = 36$ pairs of vertices determines two equilateral triangles, for a total of 72 triangles.
 However, the three triangles $A_1A_4A_7$, $A_2A_5A_8$, and $A_3A_6A_9$ are each counted 3 times, resulting in an overcount of 6.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{66}$ distinct equilateral triangles.
 *)

theorem
fixes n_equilateral_triangles :: nat
assumes h0 : "n_equilateral_triangles = card {T. T \<subseteq> {A1, A2, A3, A4, A5, A6, A7, A8, A9} \<and> (\<exists> P Q R. P \<in> T \<and> Q \<in> T \<and> R \<in> T \<and> dist P Q = dist Q R \<and> dist P R = dist Q R)}"
shows  "n_equilateral_triangles = 66"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: How many equilateral triangles can be formed using any combination of three vertices from a set of 9 distinct points? The final answer is 66.
